sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Temani Afif)
articles.description: Let’s play with images and experiment with CSS masks. The idea is fairly simple: take a single `` tag and harness the power of CSS to accomplish complex hover transitions. Through different demos, you will see how CSS masks combined with gradients allow us to create fancy effects — with efficient, reusable code.
articles.title: Revealing Images With CSS Mask Animations

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ben Shih)
articles.description: Running a workshop can be an effective alternative to traditional, long-standing meetings. To help ensure its success, Ben Shih introduces the concept of an inclusive workshop. In Part 1 of the series, you discover the fundamentals of inclusivity and get some solid guidance on how to plan an inclusive remote workshop.
articles.title: Facilitating Inclusive Online Workshops (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Preethi Samathanam)
articles.description: Gradients are a powerful CSS feature. We use them for texture, depth, and even to hide parts of elements with CSS masking. This article covers another interesting way to use gradients — as a hover effect that affects the appearance of other elements around the hovered element.
articles.title: Gradients, Blend Modes, And A Really Cool Hover Effect

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Pratik Joglekar)
articles.description: Pratik Joglekar takes a philosophical approach to remind designers about the lost joy within themselves by effectively placing massive importance on mindfulness, introspection, and forward-looking. Without joy, the work we do would feel meaningless. To prevent it from happening, check out a few ideas that would help rediscover that spark of joy.
articles.title: Rediscovering The Joy Of Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ramona Schwering)
articles.description: Is the Test Pyramid really dead? Discover the more contemporary testing strategies and evaluate the Test Pyramid’s relevance in today’s software development practices.
articles.title: Long Live The Test Pyramid

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Joas Pambou)
articles.description: In this article, Joas Pambou builds the tool to provide a sentiment score in **real-time** with enhanced user experience by providing multilingual support. You will use an OpenAI library called Whisper that transcribes audio files into text and detects the language, and Gradio, a UI framework, to establish the interface.
articles.title: Generating Real-Time Audio Sentiment Analysis With AI

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s get ready for September with some fresh wallpaper designs! Created with love by artists and designers from across the globe, the wallpapers in this collection come in versions with and without a calendar. Enjoy!
articles.title: A September Of Never Ending Adventures (2023 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: The CSS Color Module Level 4 specification defined a slew of new color features when it became a candidate recommendation in 2022, including Oklab and Oklch, which have widened the field of color we have to work with. Explore the Oklch color space and how to start using it in CSS today.
articles.title: Falling For Oklch: A Love Story Of Color Spaces, Gamuts, And CSS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Budd)
articles.description: The so-called “Double Diamond” is a great way of visualizing an ideal design process — but it’s just not the way most companies deliver new projects or services. Andy Budd proposes a new “Double Diamond” idea that better aligns with the way work actually gets done and highlights the place where design has the most leverage.
articles.title: Improving The Double Diamond Design Process

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Preethi Sam)
articles.description: We often think of shadows in CSS as something to reach for when we want to add depth to a design. But shadows can be used for more than depth. Let’s experiment with different shadows — two CSS properties and a filter — to make interesting hover effects, different text styles, and even casting shadows on other shadows.
articles.title: A Few Interesting Ways To Use CSS Shadows For More Than Depth

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Costa Alexoglou)
articles.description: Discover how to improve the user experience of nested menus and tackle a minor yet common issue with them when the user’s pointer leaves the menu item for a moment, and the nested menu goes away, requiring the user to re-hover and try again. A well-known concept called the “safe triangle” solves this problem.
articles.title: Better Context Menus With Safe Triangles
